dek: What our bodies do for work

stand_sit.text: Tell me a bit about your job.

body.text: What are physical requirements for your job?

environment.text: Finally, tell me about your work environment.

story.text: This circle represents a job that has similar physical requirements to yours. Each inside dot represents about 50,000 Americans who do that job.
↑ Some similar jobs pay more. ↓ Some pay less.
← These jobs on the left have very different physical demands from your job →
In the middle is every other job in America.
This story is about the divide between people who sit for living—and those who stand, crouch, crawl, and lift.
American jobs became less physically demanding over the past century. But many workers still work physically demanding jobs today.

story.hl: Percent of workers, crouching is required
story.text: For example, these are the people who said they are required to crouch – everyone from nurses to electricians.

story.hl: Percent of workers, climbing ladders, ropes, or scaffolds is required
story.text: Many workers said they are required to climb ladders, ropes, or scaffolds. It includes firefighters and janitors.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to wetness
story.text: Many workers face environmental hazards. This is who is exposed to wetness, like water, sewage, or bodily fluids.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to extreme heat
story.text: This is who is exposed to extreme heat from things like stoves and fires.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to outdoors
story.text: As we experience more heat waves, people who work outdoors will face increasing risks from overheating.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to hazardous contaminants
story.text: And this is who is exposed to hazardous contaminants, including mechanics and construction workers.
But having some autonomy over our work can make physically grueling jobs a bit more bearable.

story.hl: Percent of day where standing is required, mean
story.text: But many workers are required to stand most of the day.

story.hl: Percent of day where sitting is required, mean
story.text: Many workers are required to sit most of the day.

story.hl: Percent of workers, without the ability to pause work
story.text: And many workers lack control over when they can take a break.

story.hl: Percent of workers, with telework available
story.text: We’ve spent the last few years hand-wringing about remote work—but only a tiny portion of workers say they can work remotely.

story.hl: Percent of workers, problem solving is required less often than monthly, including never
story.text: A lot of American work is still physical. In fact, many workers say their jobs never require problem-solving.

story.hl: Percent of workers, problem solving is required once per day
story.text: In fact, only a tiny portion of workers say their job require daily problem-solving.
When I was a kid in the 1980s, my father was studying to be an engineer. For various reasons, he chose to leave school to earn some money.

story.job: Laborers and freight, stock, and material movers, hand
story.text: My parents tried running a dry cleaner, a car stereo store, and finally a vending machine business. They were exhausting, physically demanding jobs.

story.job: Laborers and freight, stock, and material movers, hand
story.text: One day my dad was late coming home.
He had gotten his hand stuck in a vending machine gear. He had to call 9-1-1 to get it unstuck.
A year later, my dad chose to go back to school to be an engineer. He’s loved it ever since.
I often wonder what would’ve happened if he had no ability to escape that life—if he had no choice but to let his job erode his physical health.
